executive_summary: The convention and bureaus industry markets and promotes communities and local facilities to business and leisure travelers. Operators also assist customers in locating meeting and convention sites and planning and supporting associated events. Revenue jumped over most of the past five years, but the negative effects of the pandemic challenged this trend.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The pandemic negatively impacted the industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Tourism's immense economic benefits have significantly shaped the composition of this industry. Some operators are private companies, some receive public assistance, while others operate as a combination of both sectors. In 2020, operators experienced sharp declines in revenue as consumer spending and domestic trips by US residents fell. Also, international tourist visits to the United States fell during the year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Domestic growth boosts revenue and profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the economy strengthened during most of the period, per capita disposable income jumped. This, coupled with a hike in consumer spending.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Factors Will Support Revenue Expansion Over The Coming Years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumer spending and corporate profit jump, consumers and companies are expected to allocate a greater share of budgets to travel, going on vacations and attending meetings and conferences.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The industry will remain sensitive to general economic factors and other trends
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will remain sensitive to general economic factors and other trends, including natural disasters, health scares, geopolitical instability and fears of terrorism, which influence demand for travel by US residents and foreign visitors.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Travel is expected to accelerate, benefitting the industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The number of domestic trips taken by US residents is expected to accelerate as consumers go on trips that were initially postponed because of travel restrictions during the pandemic in the current period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Some remaining challenges may pressure demand for services
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Changes in the relative price of domestic and international travel, linked to exchange rate movements, influence revenue performance. The industry benefits when traveling in the US becomes comparatively less expensive than traveling abroad.

industry_definition: This industry markets and promotes communities and local facilities to business and leisure travelers. Operators assist customers in locating meeting and convention sites. They also provide travel information on an area's attractions and accommodations and provide maps and information brochures. Operators also organize group tours of local historical, recreational and cultural attractions.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Competition is typically confined to local or regional areas. Visitor bureaus work to promote their state or city to attract as many tourists as possible. Their efforts aim to boost local economies through increased tourism revenue.
Online competition has surged, impacting local travel arrangements
COVID-19 stalled revenue growth in recent years

Economic improvements will drive future revenue. Increasing consumer spending and corporate profit are set to boost leisure and business travel, and enhanced financial health is expected to benefit the travel industry overall.
Some states require local business promotion

market_segmentation.segment_description: Leisure travelers aged 34 and younger make up the largest market for the industry, accounting for over one-third of revenue. This customer demographic benefits from being the least time-constrained, allowing them to take more vacations.

Leisure travelers aged 35-64 comprise the industry's second-largest market and account for over one-third of revenue. This is because of the stable income that individuals in this age group earn annually.

Leisure travelers aged 65 and older account for the smallest market segment in the industry. This customer demographic has abundant leisure time but doesn't often desire to make as many trips as their younger counterparts. Because of the pandemic, travel in this segment declined as this demographic was at the most risk. Although, the vaccine rollout has helped this segment rebound from pandemic-induced travel lows.

Most earnings in this segment are related to services associated with conventions, expositions and fairs. The pandemic pressured this segment's share of revenue. Social distancing regulations and work-from-home operations dramatically decreased demand from this segment as events were canceled and meetings moved from in-person to video calls. As restrictions have eased and businesses continue to return to in-person operations, this market segment has rebounded following the pandemic. However, the record-high inflation rate has reduced corporations' budgets for business trips.

products_and_services.product_description: Convention conference and meeting planning surged after COVID-19 restrictions were lifted. These events gained popularity as in-person interactions resumed and workers returned to their offices, fueling a renewed demand for face-to-face gatherings.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Visitor Information and Sightseeing Tour Services
products_and_services.product_description: Many visitor bureaus are nonprofit companies funded by government and membership levies to boost visitors to a state or city. Visitor bureaus promote and market particular cities to tourists.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Convention Support, Travel Reservation and Other Services
products_and_services.product_description: Other services offered include tourism research services, training workshops in tourism and related subjects and other assorted tourism support services.

tier_1_suppliers: Trade Show and Conference Planning in the US
Magazine & Periodical Publishing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Office Supply Stores in the US
tier_1_buyers: Trade Show and Conference Planning in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Higher levels of consumer spending indicate that households have more discretionary spending power, resulting in increased expenditure on luxury experiences like travel. Industry revenue depends on travel and the need for travel support services, so higher consumer spending bodes well for this industry.

business_locations.location_description: Convention and visitor bureau businesses are concentrated heavily in the Southeast region of the United States, with a relatively substantial portion of establishments located there. Within the Southeast, Florida stands out as a prime destination. Its wide array of tourist attractions—including renowned beaches, consistently warm weather and major destinations like Walt Disney World—draw numerous travelers, making it a strategic choice for operators looking to maximize visibility and clientele.

The West region has the highest concentration of operators in the country, making up a relatively large portion of establishments. California tops the list as the leading tourist destination, boasting the largest share of these establishments. California's alluring beaches and national parks greatly attract tourists, providing a significant business boost. The combination of natural beauty and recreational opportunities makes California an ideal location for convention and visitor bureaus.

The Mid-Atlantic region hosts the third-largest concentration of establishments in the United States. This area is strategically favorable due to its dense population and rich cultural history. New York draws the most visitors in the region, with Pennsylvania following closely. This attraction is largely due to New York's historical landmarks like the Empire State Building and the Statue of Liberty, as well as its world-renowned museums. These factors make New York a top tourist destination and a prime location for convention and visitor bureaus.

regulations_points.regulation_description: State legislation mandates local businesses to be the only ones to provide products and services promoted at visitor bureaus. Some states allow tourism bureaus to create marketing campaigns within specific frameworks, while others offer grant-matching programs to support nonprofit organizations promoting travel and vacation businesses.

The pandemic introduced significant regulations affecting convention and visitor bureaus. Stay-at-home orders and social distancing rules led to a major drop in tourism. Businesses that continued operating had to comply with these measures, limiting the capacity of tours and sightseeing activities.

barriers_points.barrier_description: States legislate that visitor bureaus promote products and services offered only by local businesses. Some states allow bureaus to design marketing campaigns within specific frameworks, impacting market strategies and operational flexibility.

New entrants need capital for computer reservation systems, a robust internet presence and comprehensive marketing through ads, brochures and literature. These initial expenses can be substantial and challenging to manage.

Introducing a new service or destination is the most significant barrier to entry. Many areas aren't attractive to tourists, making it hard to draw interest and differentiate from established destinations.

The industry is labor-intensive, requiring staff for convention planning, support and marketing. Employees utilize strategies to position areas as tourist destinations, highlighting the high costs associated with skilled labor.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition is typically confined to local or regional areas. Visitor bureaus work to promote their state or city to attract as many tourists as possible. Their efforts aim to boost local economies through increased tourism revenue.

Online competition has surged, impacting local travel arrangements. By bypassing traditional travel services, online competitors promote independent travel and offer more direct booking options, challenging the local travel industry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Larger Operators Located in Traditional Tourist Areas Better Exploit Economies of Scale
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger operators in traditional tourist areas can exploit economies of scale better than smaller operators. With more accommodations and a comprehensive selection of entertainment and leisure options to market to potential guests, large operators can market a more enjoyable experience than smaller operators in less traditionally tourism-centric locations.
Large operators can respond quickly to customers' preferences concerning online infrastructure that enables individuals to browse operators' sites and book travel arrangements conveniently.

concentration_points.concentration_title: THE VAST EXPANSE OF AREAS AND RANGE OF ATTRACTIONS NATIONWIDE RESULTS IN A FRAGMENTED INDUSTRY
concentration_points.concentration_description: Operators market and hold events only in their respective regions. For instance, a New York bureau won't promote Hawaii attractions. This ensures focused marketing efforts and localized expertise for better customer engagement.

Smaller companies in less tourism-heavy areas lack extensive marketing resources and are highly prone to closure. These businesses can't match the outreach of larger firms and often struggle to survive without robust tourist traffic, increasing their risk of shutdown.

top_companies.company_name: Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Expand, Remaining the Most Significant Expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include items bought by operators that are repackaged for resale and items bought for use at events and conventions. Operators often put together large-scale packages for convention delegates or attendees, assembling accommodations for thousands of consumers at a time for heavily attended events.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGES REMAIN IMPORTANT DESPITE INTERNET TECHNOLOGY IMPLEMENTATION SINCE EMPLOYEES ARE STILL NEEDED TO PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY SERVICES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Operators assemble, market and sell travel items and packages, including air and ground transportation, hotel accommodations, restaurant vouchers and local maps and guides. Despite implementing various computer and internet technologies, the industry still depends on personal contacts, networking and hands-on local knowledge.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PROFIT INCREASES AS DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL REBOUND FOLLOWING THE PANDEMIC
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: There is a discrepancy between larger operators and smaller counterparts and for-profit and nonprofit companies. Smaller operators exist in the visitor bureau space and operate on much thinner profit, generating less revenue. Profit dropped in 2020 because of the pandemic's negative impact on the global economy and domestic and international travel.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is labor-intensive, requiring staff for convention planning, support and marketing. Employees utilize strategies to position areas as tourist destinations, highlighting the high costs associated with skilled labor.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic factors and the pandemic impact volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is sensitive to general economic conditions and other issues that impact travel arrangements or demand, including natural disasters.

volatility_points.volatility_title: INCREASED COMPETITION AND OVERALL TOURISM CAUSE VOLATILITY TO SPIKE
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry has competed with online travel sites, with travelers able to find area information and book travel arrangements directly through the internet. Steady increases in domestic and international tourism, except for 2020, kept revenue growing relatively steadily for most of the last five years.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Operators increasingly use the internet to attract customers
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Operators have encountered increased competition from companies offering similar services online. The shift to using internet services to reach a broader audience has benefitted operators in the industry. The pandemic exacerbated this trend.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Online features enable operators to become more efficient
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The internet enables 24/7 sales operations, enhancing efficiency and effectiveness. This constant availability helps businesses meet customer needs anytime, maximizing potential revenue and streamlining operational processes.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators that offer bundled packages that include hotel rooms, air fair and activities for clients will attract consumers.

FAQs.question: How dependent are you on the public sector?
FAQs.answer: The industry as a symbiotic relationship with the public sector. Industry players often receive funding from the public sector, and industry earnings are funneled back into the public sector.

FAQs.question: Does your business need to be located near key consumer or client markets?
FAQs.answer: Operators located in high-density tourist areas benefit from increased demand.

FAQs.question: Is obtaining long-term contracts with customers essential to your business' success?
FAQs.answer: Industry players that are able to help host and promote recurring events on an annual or semiannual basis benefit from high revenue.

FAQs.question: Does your company use mobile applications to improve client services and consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: Many industry players are implementing new technology, such as apps and websites, in order to provide services outside of normal business hours.

FAQs.question: Does your company use mobile applications to reduce labor costs and improve employee efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Wages have increased as a share of revenue in recent years, inducing companies to automate more operational processes to reduce labor costs.

FAQs.question: Is obtaining state certification or licensing necessary for your business?
FAQs.answer: Most industry players work closely with the state government, though licensing requirements are low.

FAQs.question: Is your business responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Industry players often host and organize events for large companies and organizations. They are often responsible for safeguarding information for these companies and organizations.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: The industry experiences the highest level of demand during the summer and holiday months. By charging higher rates during these peak times, industry players make up for time of low demand.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Industry players depreciate assets such as tables and light fixtures, keeping new purchases low.

FAQs.question: Does your company undertake market research efforts? What outreach campaigns have been most successful for you?
FAQs.answer: Operators undertake extensive market research to understand the needs and motivations of travelers. Meeting these needs encourages new visitors and ensures repeat visits.

FAQs.question: What training is required of your staff? Are your employees able to perform multiple roles as needed?
FAQs.answer: Many operators require staff to fulfill a variety of roles, such as marketing, packaging and selling travel items, general office and administrative duties and customer relations.

FAQs.question: Is your business located in a favorable area? In what ways can your physical establishment set itself apart from online competitors?
FAQs.answer: Many operators are located in high tourist traffic areas, such as near central business districts, airports and major attractions.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in leisure time? When do you find your services to be most in demand?
FAQs.answer: The more leisure time people have, the more likely they will be to take vacations and travel. When individuals travel, they are more likely to use industry services to book excursions or get information about their travel destination.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in corporate profit? Do you experience revenue gains when corporate profit is high?
FAQs.answer: Changes in corporate profit have an effect on travel intentions and expenditure. When companies have higher profit, they have more room in their budget to host events or send employees on traveling business.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor consumer spending patterns? What consumers do you target in your outreach efforts, and how do you appeal to them?
FAQs.answer: Higher levels of consumer spending indicate households have more discretionary spending power, and thus, can increase expenditure on luxury experiences, such as travel. Industry revenue depends on travel, so higher consumer spending bodes well for this industry.
